User-Level Privacy-Preserving Federated Learning: Analysis and Performance Optimization

Kang Wei,  Jun Li,  Ming Ding,  Chuan Ma, Hang Su,  Bo Zhang,  and H. Vincent Poor Kang Wei, Jun Li (corresponding author) and Chuan Ma are with School of Electrical and Optical Engineering, Nanjing University of Science and Technology, Nanjing, China. E-mail: {kang.wei, jun.li, chuan.ma}@njust.edu.cn. Ming Ding is with Data61, CSIRO, Sydney, Australia. E-mail: ming.ding@data61.csiro.au. Hang Su and Bo Zhang are with Department of Computer Science and Technology, Tsinghua University, Beijing, China. E-mail: {suhangss, dcszb}@tsinghua.edu.cn. H. Vincent Poor is with Department of Electrical Engineering, Princeton University, NJ, USA. E-mail: poor@princeton.edu.Manuscript received April 19, 2005; revised August 26, 2015.
Abstract

Federated learning (FL), as a type of collaborative machine learning framework, is capable of preserving private data from mobile terminals (MTs) while training the data into useful models. Nevertheless, from a viewpoint of information theory, it is still possible for a curious server to infer private information from the shared models uploaded by MTs. To address this problem, we first make use of the concept of local differential privacy (LDP), and propose a user-level differential privacy (UDP) algorithm by adding artificial noise to the shared models before uploading them to servers. According to our analysis, the UDP framework can realize (ϵi,δi)subscriptitalic-ϵ𝑖subscript𝛿𝑖(\epsilon_{i},\delta_{i})-LDP for the i𝑖i-th MT with adjustable privacy protection levels by varying the variances of the artificial noise processes. We then derive a theoretical convergence upper-bound for the UDP algorithm. It reveals that there exists an optimal number of communication rounds to achieve the best learning performance. More importantly, we propose a communication rounds discounting (CRD) method. Compared with the heuristic search method, the proposed CRD method can achieve a much better trade-off between the computational complexity of searching and the convergence performance. Extensive experiments indicate that our UDP algorithm using the proposed CRD method can effectively improve both the training efficiency and model quality for the given privacy protection levels.

Index Terms:
Federated learning, differential privacy, communication round, mobile edge computing.

1 Introduction

With the dramatic development of the internet-of-things (IoT), the amount of data originating from intelligent devices is growing at unprecedented rates [1, 2]. Conventional machine learning (ML) is no longer capable of efficiently processing such data in a centralized manner. To address this challenge, several distributed ML architectures have been proposed with different approaches of aggregating gradients or models [3]. However, data privacy and confidentiality [4, 5, 6] are of concern in such approaches as exchanged gradients or models usually contain clients’ sensitive information. One such distributed ML architecture is federated learning (FL), which allows a decoupling of data provision at end-user equipment (UE) and machine learning model aggregation at a central server [7, 8]. In FL, all mobile terminals (MTs) with the same data structure collaboratively learn a shared model with the help of a server, i.e., training the model at MTs and aggregating model parameters at the server. Owing to the local training, FL does not require MTs to upload their private data, thereby effectively reducing transmission overhead as well as promoting MTs’ privacy. As such, FL is applicable to a variety of scenarios where data are either sensitive or expensive to be transmitted to the server, e.g., health-care records, private images, and personally identifiable information, etc. [9, 10, 11].

Although FL can help prevent private data from being exposed to the public, hidden adversaries may attack the learning model by eavesdropping and analyzing the shared parameters, e.g., via a reconstruction attack [12] or an inference attack [13]. For example, a malicious classifier may reveal the features of the MTs’ data and reconstruct data points from the FL training process [12]. Some designed attack strategies can be found in recent studies. The work in [14] recovered the private data based on the observation that the gradient of weights is proportional to that of the bias, and their ratio approximates the training input. The work in [12] considered an untrusted server in FL and proposed a generative adversarial network (GAN) based reconstruction attack. Furthermore, this reconstruction attack utilized the shared model as the discriminator to train a GAN [15] model that generates original samples of the training data. In [13], Melis et al. demonstrated that the shared models in FL may leak unintended information from participants’ training data, and they developed passive and active inference attacks to exploit this leakage. The work in [16] showed that it is possible to obtain the private training data from the publicly shared gradients, i.e., deep leakage from gradient, which was empirically validated on both computer vision and natural language processing tasks. The work in [12] proposed a novel GAN framework with a multi-task discriminator at the server side to attack user-level privacy, which can simultaneously discriminate category, reality, and user identity of input samples. Therefore, it is challenging to preserve data contributors’ privacy from [17].

Therefore, privacy-preserving ML has attracted intensive attention in recent years, as the emergence of centralized searchable data repositories and open data applications may lead to the leakage of private information. The work in [3] first proposed the concept of deep learning with DP, providing an evaluation criterion for privacy guarantees. The work in [18] improved DP based stochastic gradient descent (SGD) algorithms by carefully allocation of a privacy budget at each training iteration. In [18], the privacy budget and step size for each iteration are dynamically determined at runtime based on the quality of the noisy statistics (e.g., gradient) obtained for the current training iteration. Privacy issues are also more critical in distributed ML. The work in [19] introduced the notion of DP in distributed ML and proposed a distributed online learning algorithm to improve the learning performance for a given privacy level. The work in [20] analyzed the privacy loss in a DP-based distributed ML framework, and provided the explicit convergence performance. The work in [21] presented a theoretical analysis of DP-based SGD algorithms, and provided an approach for analyzing the quality of ML models related to the privacy level and the size of the datasets.

A formal treatment of privacy risks in FL calls for a holistic and interdisciplinary approach [22]. The work in  [23] proposed an FL algorithm based on a random sub-sampling scheduling at each aggregation. This algorithm can achieve good training performance at a given privacy level when there are a sufficiently large number of participating MTs. However, it cannot preserve MTs’ private information from being exposed to a curious server. The work in [24] presented an alternative approach that utilizes both DP and secure multiparty computation (SMC) to protect against inference threats and produces models with high accuracy. A key component of this work is the ability to reduce noise by leveraging the SMC framework while considering a customizable trust parameter, which will also consume more communication and computing resources. The work in [25] involved sketching algorithms, using hash functions to compress the input data with bounded errors, to consider communication efficiency and privacy protection in distributed learning. However, some of these approaches cannot preserve MTs’ private information from being exposed to the curious server. Moreover, other approaches, such as SMC and sketching algorithms, can consume large amounts of communications and computer resources.

To solve these challenges, it is important to design an effective algorithm to mitigate the privacy concerns for data sharing without deteriorating the quality of trained FL models. In this paper, in order to prevent information leakage from the shared model parameters and improve the training efficiency, we develop a novel privacy-preserving FL framework, termed the user-level differential privacy (UDP) algorithm. Furthermore, we develop a theoretical convergence bound for this UDP algorithm and design a novel online optimization method to achieve better convergence performance compared with the original UDP algorithm.

Specifically, the contributions of this paper can be summarized as follows:

  • ∙∙\bullet

    We introduce a novel privacy-preserving FL framework, namely the user-level differential privacy (UDP) algorithm, using the concept of local differential privacy (LDP) and verify that this UDP framework can realize (ϵi,δi)subscriptitalic-ϵ𝑖subscript𝛿𝑖(\epsilon_{i},\delta_{i})-LDP for the i𝑖i-th MT for iterative learning model exchange with a curious server based on our analysis.

  • ∙∙\bullet

    We enhance a standard differential privacy (DP) mechanism (the moments accountant method) and analyze the sensitivity for each MT under the LDP definition. Then, we prove that the training process of the i𝑖i-th MT satisfies the requirement of (ϵi,δi)subscriptitalic-ϵ𝑖subscript𝛿𝑖(\epsilon_{i},\delta_{i})-LDP for different privacy levels by properly adapting their variances of Gaussian noise added to the model updates.

  • ∙∙\bullet

    We also show that there exists an optimal number of communication rounds in terms of convergence performance for a given privacy level. This property demonstrates that we need to have a new look at communication rounds. Thus, we design an online optimization method, termed communication rounds discounting (CRD), which can obtain a better tradeoff between complexity and convergence performance compared with the original UDP algorithm and an offline heuristic search method.

  • ∙∙\bullet

    We conduct extensive experiments on real-word datasets and the experimental results validate that our CRD method in UDP can achieve performance equivalent to that of offline search in terms of loss function values, but with a much lower complexity.

The remainder of this paper is organized as follows. The threat model and background on LDP and FL are presented in Section 2. Then, we provide the details of the proposed UDP algorithm and the privacy analysis in Section 3, and present the noise recalculation and CRD methods in Section 4. The analytical and experimental results are shown in Section 5. Finally, conclusions are drawn in Section 6.

2 Preliminaries

In this section, we first present the FL framework and the threat model, and then introduce the basic knowledge of (ϵ,δ)italic-ϵ𝛿(\epsilon,\delta)-LDP.

2.1 Federated Learning

Let us consider a general FL system consisting of a centralized server and U𝑈U MTs. Let 𝒟isubscript𝒟𝑖\mathcal{D}_{i} denote the local dataset held by MT 𝒞isubscript𝒞𝑖\mathcal{C}_{i}, where 𝒰={1,2,…,U}𝒰12…𝑈\mathcal{U}=\{1,2,\ldots,U\} and i∈𝒰𝑖𝒰i\in\mathcal{U}. For all participants, the objective is to learn a global model over data that resides at the U𝑈U associated MTs. Formally, this FL task can be expressed as

𝒘∗=arg⁡min𝒘F​(𝒟,𝒘),superscript𝒘subscript𝒘𝐹𝒟𝒘\boldsymbol{w}^{*}=\mathop{\arg\min}_{\boldsymbol{w}}{F(\mathcal{D},\boldsymbol{w})}, (1)

where F​(𝒟,𝒘)=∑i∈𝒰pi​Fi​(𝒟i,𝒘)𝐹𝒟𝒘subscript𝑖𝒰subscript𝑝𝑖subscript𝐹𝑖subscript𝒟𝑖𝒘F(\mathcal{D},\boldsymbol{w})=\sum_{i\in\mathcal{U}}p_{i}F_{i}(\mathcal{D}_{i},\boldsymbol{w}), Fi​(⋅)subscript𝐹𝑖⋅F_{i}(\cdot) is the local loss function of the i𝑖i-th MT, pi=|𝒟i|/|𝒟|≥0subscript𝑝𝑖subscript𝒟𝑖𝒟0p_{i}=|\mathcal{D}_{i}|/|\mathcal{D}|\geq 0 with ∑i∈𝒰pi=1subscript𝑖𝒰subscript𝑝𝑖1\sum_{i\in\mathcal{U}}{p_{i}}=1, |𝒟i|subscript𝒟𝑖|\mathcal{D}_{i}| is the number of data samples in the i𝑖i-th MT’s dataset and |𝒟|=∑i∈𝒰|𝒟i|𝒟subscript𝑖𝒰subscript𝒟𝑖|\mathcal{D}|=\sum_{i\in\mathcal{U}}{|\mathcal{D}_{i}|} is the total number of data samples in all MTs’ datasets, respectively. Generally, the local loss functions Fi​(⋅)subscript𝐹𝑖⋅F_{i}(\cdot) are given by local empirical risks and have the same expression for various MTs. At the server, K𝐾K MTs are chosen and a model aggregation is performed over their uploaded models. In particular, 𝒘𝒘\boldsymbol{w} is the global model parameter, given by

𝒘=∑i∈𝒦pi​𝒘i,𝒘subscript𝑖𝒦subscript𝑝𝑖subscript𝒘𝑖\boldsymbol{w}=\sum_{i\in\mathcal{K}}{p_{i}\boldsymbol{w}_{i}}, (2)

where 𝒘isubscript𝒘𝑖\boldsymbol{w}_{i} is the parameter vector trained at the i𝑖i-th MT, 𝒦𝒦\mathcal{K} is a subset of 𝒰𝒰\mathcal{U}, with K𝐾K MTs out of U𝑈U MTs chosen for participating in the model aggregation, respectively. To facilitate analysis on the privacy performance, in this paper, we adopt a low complexity method, termed K𝐾K-user random scheduling, in which K𝐾K MTs are randomly chosen from all the MTs.

2.2 Threat Model

In this paper, we assume that the server is honest-but-curious, which means it will strictly follow the FL rule, but may recover the training datasets [12] or infer private features [13] based on the local uploaded parameters. Concretely, this curious server can train a GAN framework, e.g., multi-task GAN-AI [12], which may simultaneously discriminates category, reality, and user identity of input samples. This novel discrimination on user identity enables the generator to recover users’ private data. In addition, this curious server may also be interested in learning whether a given sample belongs to the training datasets, which can be inferred by utilizing the difference between model outputs from training and non-training this sample [26]. For example, when FL is conducting a clinical experiment, a participant may not want the observer to know whether he is involved in this experiment (a MT may contain several individuals’ records). However, the adversary may link the test results to the appearance or disappearance of this participant, and then possibly inflict harm to this person. Therefore, our threat model is reasonable and realistic.

2.3 Local Differential Privacy

DP mechanism with parameters ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon and δ𝛿\delta provides a strong criterion for the privacy preservation of distributed data processing systems. Here, ϵ>0italic-ϵ0\epsilon>0 is the distinguishable bound of all outputs on neighboring datasets x,x′𝑥superscript𝑥′x,x^{\prime} in a database 𝒳𝒳\mathcal{X}, and δ𝛿\delta represents the probability of the event that the ratio of the probabilities for two adjacent datasets x,x′𝑥superscript𝑥′x,x^{\prime} cannot be bounded by eϵsuperscript𝑒italic-ϵe^{\epsilon} after adding a privacy-preserving mechanism. With an arbitrarily given δ𝛿\delta, a larger ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon gives a clearer distinguishability of neighboring datasets and hence a higher risk of privacy violation. Now, we will formally define LDP as follows.

Definition 1

((ϵ,δ)italic-ϵ𝛿(\epsilon,\delta)-LDP [27]): A randomized mechanism ℳℳ\mathcal{M} satisfies (ϵ,δ)italic-ϵ𝛿(\epsilon,\delta)-DP: 𝒳→ℛ→𝒳ℛ\mathcal{X}\rightarrow\mathcal{R} with domain 𝒳𝒳\mathcal{X} and range ℛℛ\mathcal{R}, for all measurable sets 𝒮⊆ℛ𝒮ℛ\mathcal{S}\subseteq\mathcal{R} and any two adjacent datasets x,x′∈𝒳𝑥superscript𝑥′𝒳x,x^{\prime}\in\mathcal{X}, we have

Pr​[ℳ​(x)∈𝒮]≤eϵ​Pr​[ℳ​(x′)∈𝒮]+δ.Prdelimited-[]ℳ𝑥𝒮superscript𝑒italic-ϵPrdelimited-[]ℳsuperscript𝑥′𝒮𝛿\emph{Pr}[\mathcal{M}(x)\in\mathcal{S}]\leq e^{\epsilon}\emph{Pr}[\mathcal{M}(x^{\prime})\in\mathcal{S}]+\delta. (2)

In this paper, we choose the Gaussian mechanism that adopts L2subscript𝐿2L_{2} norm sensitivity. It adds zero-mean Gaussian noise with variance σ2​𝐈superscript𝜎2𝐈\sigma^{2}\mathbf{I} in each coordinate of the function output s​(x)𝑠𝑥s(x) as

ℳ​(x)=s​(x)+𝒩​(0,σ2​𝐈),ℳ𝑥𝑠𝑥𝒩0superscript𝜎2𝐈\mathcal{M}(x)=s(x)+\mathcal{N}(0,\sigma^{2}\mathbf{I}), (3)

where 𝐈𝐈\mathbf{I} is an identity matrix and has the same size with s​(x)𝑠𝑥s(x). The sensitivity of the function s𝑠s can be expressed as

Δ​s=maxx,x′∈𝒳⁡‖s​(x)−s​(x′)‖2,Δ𝑠subscript𝑥superscript𝑥′𝒳subscriptnorm𝑠𝑥𝑠superscript𝑥′2\Delta s=\max_{x,x^{\prime}\in\mathcal{X}}\|s(x)-s(x^{\prime})\|_{2}, (4)

which gives an upper bound on how much we must perturb its output considering preserving privacy. It satisfies (ϵ,δ)italic-ϵ𝛿(\epsilon,\delta)-LDP when we properly select the value of σ𝜎\sigma.

3 Privacy Analysis

In this section, we first propose a user-level differential privacy (UDP) algorithm in FL against the curious server. Then, we develop a method for analyzing the privacy loss moment by improving the conventional analysis approach [3]. Based on our improved method, we are able to accurately calculate the standard deviation (STD) of additive noises in UDP to guarantee (ϵi,δi)subscriptitalic-ϵ𝑖subscript𝛿𝑖(\epsilon_{i},\delta_{i})-LDP for the i𝑖i-th MT.

3.1 User-level DP

In this subsection, to prevent information leakage from uploaded parameters, we will introduce a UDP algorithm, which borrows the concept of LDP. Our UDP algorithm is outlined in Algorithm 1 for training an effective model with the (ϵi,δi)subscriptitalic-ϵ𝑖subscript𝛿𝑖(\epsilon_{i},\delta_{i})-LDP guarantee for the i𝑖i-th MT. We can note that all MTs have their own privacy parameters ϵisubscriptitalic-ϵ𝑖\epsilon_{i} and δisubscript𝛿𝑖\delta_{i}. We denote by T𝑇T the number of communication rounds, by 𝒘0superscript𝒘0\boldsymbol{w}^{0} the initial global parameter, by σisubscript𝜎𝑖\sigma_{i} the STD of additive noises for the i𝑖i-th MT, by t𝑡t the index of the current communication round and by q𝑞q the random sampling ratio (q=K/U𝑞𝐾𝑈q=K/U).

At the beginning, the server broadcasts the initiate global parameter 𝒘0superscript𝒘0\boldsymbol{w}^{0} and T𝑇T to all MTs. Then, K𝐾K active MTs are chosen and train the model parameters by using local datasets with preset terminal conditions, respectively. During the local training, the local gradients 𝒈i,mt,∀m∈{1,…,|𝒟i|}subscriptsuperscript𝒈𝑡𝑖𝑚for-all𝑚1…subscript𝒟𝑖\boldsymbol{g}^{t}_{i,m},\forall m\in\{1,\ldots,|\mathcal{D}_{i}|\} are clipped by the threshold C𝐶C. After the local training, the i𝑖i-th MT, ∀i∈𝒦for-all𝑖𝒦\forall i\in\mathcal{K}, will add noises to the trained model parameters 𝒘it+1subscriptsuperscript𝒘𝑡1𝑖\boldsymbol{w}^{t+1}_{i}, in which σi2superscriptsubscript𝜎𝑖2\sigma_{i}^{2} is the variance of artificial noises and this value is calculated by the i𝑖i-th MT according to the privacy level (ϵi,δi)subscriptitalic-ϵ𝑖subscript𝛿𝑖(\epsilon_{i},\delta_{i}), sampling ratio q𝑞q and the number of communication rounds T𝑇T. When all active MTs finish local training process, they are required to upload the noised parameters 𝒘~it+1subscriptsuperscriptbold-~𝒘𝑡1𝑖\boldsymbol{\widetilde{w}}^{t+1}_{i} to the server for aggregation.

Then, the server updates the global parameters 𝒘t+1superscript𝒘𝑡1{\boldsymbol{w}}^{t+1} by aggregating the local parameters integrated with different weights according to (2) and broadcasts them to the MTs. The accuracy of each MT will be estimated based on the received global parameters 𝒘t+1superscript𝒘𝑡1\boldsymbol{w}^{t+1} using local testing datasets. If preset terminal conditions are not satisfied, all MTs will start the next round of training process based on these updated global parameters. In detail, when the aggregation time reaches a preset number of communication rounds T𝑇T, our UDP completes and returns 𝒘Tsuperscript𝒘𝑇\boldsymbol{w}^{T}. Owing to the local perturbations, it will be difficult for the honest-but-curious server to infer private features of the i𝑖i-MT. In this case, in order to effectively protect the i𝑖i-th MT privacy, the STD of additive noises will be analyzed according to the concept of (ϵi,δi)subscriptitalic-ϵ𝑖subscript𝛿𝑖(\epsilon_{i},\delta_{i})-LDP in the following sections.

3.2 Bound of the Moment

Before calculating the STD σisubscript𝜎𝑖\sigma_{i} of the additive noises, we will first enhance the classic moments accountant method in [3]. According to [3], using Gaussian mechanism, we can define privacy loss of i𝑖i-th MT after T𝑇T communication rounds in our UDP algorithm by

c≜exp⁡(αT​(λ))=exp⁡(∑t=1Tα​(λ)),≜𝑐superscript𝛼𝑇𝜆superscriptsubscript𝑡1𝑇𝛼𝜆c\triangleq\exp\left(\alpha^{T}(\lambda)\right)=\exp\left(\sum_{t=1}^{T}\alpha(\lambda)\right), (5)

where the moment generating function α​(λ)𝛼𝜆\alpha(\lambda) is given by

α​(λ)≜ln⁡(max⁡{Dν1,ν0,Dν0,ν1}),≜𝛼𝜆subscript𝐷subscript𝜈1subscript𝜈0subscript𝐷subscript𝜈0subscript𝜈1\alpha(\lambda)\triangleq\ln(\max\{D_{\nu_{1},\nu_{0}},D_{\nu_{0},\nu_{1}}\}), (6)

λ𝜆\lambda is any positive integer, ν0subscript𝜈0\nu_{0} denotes the Gaussian probability density function (PDF) of 𝒩​(0,σi2)𝒩0superscriptsubscript𝜎𝑖2\mathcal{N}(0,\sigma_{i}^{2}), ν1subscript𝜈1\nu_{1} denotes the mixture of two Gaussian distributions q​𝒩​(Δ​ℓ,σi2)+(1−q)​𝒩​(0,σi2)𝑞𝒩Δℓsuperscriptsubscript𝜎𝑖21𝑞𝒩0superscriptsubscript𝜎𝑖2q\mathcal{N}(\Delta\ell,\sigma_{i}^{2})+(1-q)\mathcal{N}(0,\sigma_{i}^{2}), q=K/U𝑞𝐾𝑈q=K/U is the random sampling ratio in UDP algorithm (means that all MTs have the same probability to be selected in the aggregation) and Δ​ℓΔℓ\Delta\ell denotes the sensitivity of the local training process ℓℓ\ell, respectively. The expression of Dν1,ν0subscript𝐷subscript𝜈1subscript𝜈0D_{\nu_{1},\nu_{0}} and Dν0,ν1subscript𝐷subscript𝜈0subscript𝜈1D_{\nu_{0},\nu_{1}} can be written as

Dν1,ν0=𝔼z∼ν1​(ν1ν0)λ=𝔼z∼ν0​(ν1ν0)λ+1,subscript𝐷subscript𝜈1subscript𝜈0subscript𝔼similar-to𝑧subscript𝜈1superscriptsubscript𝜈1subscript𝜈0𝜆subscript𝔼similar-to𝑧subscript𝜈0superscriptsubscript𝜈1subscript𝜈0𝜆1D_{\nu_{1},\nu_{0}}=\mathbb{E}_{z\sim\nu_{1}}\left(\frac{\nu_{1}}{\nu_{0}}\right)^{\lambda}=\mathbb{E}_{z\sim\nu_{0}}\left(\frac{\nu_{1}}{\nu_{0}}\right)^{\lambda+1}, (7)

and

Dν0,ν1=𝔼z∼ν0​(ν0ν1)λ=𝔼z∼ν0​(ν1ν0)−λ.subscript𝐷subscript𝜈0subscript𝜈1subscript𝔼similar-to𝑧subscript𝜈0superscriptsubscript𝜈0subscript𝜈1𝜆subscript𝔼similar-to𝑧subscript𝜈0superscriptsubscript𝜈1subscript𝜈0𝜆D_{\nu_{0},\nu_{1}}=\mathbb{E}_{z\sim\nu_{0}}\left(\frac{\nu_{0}}{\nu_{1}}\right)^{\lambda}=\mathbb{E}_{z\sim\nu_{0}}\left(\frac{\nu_{1}}{\nu_{0}}\right)^{-\lambda}. (8)

However, the derivations in [3] for the bound of moments can only be applied for the rigorous constraint q≤116​σi𝑞116subscript𝜎𝑖q\leq\frac{1}{16\sigma_{i}}. To tackle this problem, we propose Lemma 1 to further bound the moment.

Lemma 1

Considering two Gaussian distributions ν0subscript𝜈0\nu_{0} and ν1subscript𝜈1\nu_{1} used in the moments accountant method, they satisfy the following relationship:

Dν1,ν0≥Dν0,ν1.subscript𝐷subscript𝜈1subscript𝜈0subscript𝐷subscript𝜈0subscript𝜈1D_{\nu_{1},\nu_{0}}\geq D_{\nu_{0},\nu_{1}}. (9)
Proof:

See Appendix A. ∎

Note that the only difference between the Dν1,ν0subscript𝐷subscript𝜈1subscript𝜈0D_{\nu_{1},\nu_{0}} and Dν0,ν1subscript𝐷subscript𝜈0subscript𝜈1D_{\nu_{0},\nu_{1}} is the factor of λ+1𝜆1\lambda+1 and −λ𝜆-\lambda on the exponent. With Lemma 1, we can directly obtain that α​(λ)=Dν1,ν0𝛼𝜆subscript𝐷subscript𝜈1subscript𝜈0\alpha(\lambda)=D_{\nu_{1},\nu_{0}}. In this way, we can calculate the privacy loss by bound Dν1,ν0subscript𝐷subscript𝜈1subscript𝜈0D_{\nu_{1},\nu_{0}}, which can relax the constraint q≤116​σi𝑞116subscript𝜎𝑖q\leq\frac{1}{16\sigma_{i}}. In the following subsection, we will derive the STD of the Gaussian noises added in the UDP algorithm with Lemma 1.

3.3 User-level Noise Calculation

With the sensitivity and the bound of the moment, we can design the Gaussian mechanism 𝒩​(0,σi)𝒩0subscript𝜎𝑖\mathcal{N}(0,\sigma_{i}) for the i𝑖i-th MT with (ϵi,δi)subscriptitalic-ϵ𝑖subscript𝛿𝑖(\epsilon_{i},\delta_{i})-LDP requirement in terms of the sampling ratio q=K/U𝑞𝐾𝑈q=K/U and the number of communication rounds T𝑇T. The STD of the Gaussian noises can be derived according to the following theorem.

Theorem 1

Given the sampling ratio q𝑞q and the number of communication rounds T𝑇T, to guarantee (ϵi,δi)subscriptitalic-ϵ𝑖subscript𝛿𝑖(\epsilon_{i},\delta_{i})-LDP for the i𝑖i-th MT, the STD of noises σisubscript𝜎𝑖\sigma_{i} from Gaussian mechanism should satisfy

σi=Δ​ℓ​2​q​T​ln⁡(1/δi)ϵi,subscript𝜎𝑖Δℓ2𝑞𝑇1subscript𝛿𝑖subscriptitalic-ϵ𝑖\sigma_{i}=\frac{\Delta\ell\sqrt{2qT\ln(1/\delta_{i})}}{\epsilon_{i}}, (10)

where Δ​ℓΔℓ\Delta\ell is the sensitivity of the local training process and ℓ​(⋅)ℓ⋅\ell(\cdot) denotes the local training process.

Proof:

In this proof, we first need to calculate the sensitivity of the local training process defined by (4). According to the definition of LDP, we consider two adjacent datasets 𝒟i,𝒟i′∈𝒳subscript𝒟𝑖subscriptsuperscript𝒟′𝑖𝒳\mathcal{D}_{i},\mathcal{D}^{\prime}_{i}\in\mathcal{X} in the i𝑖i-th MT, where 𝒟isubscript𝒟𝑖\mathcal{D}_{i} and 𝒟i′subscriptsuperscript𝒟′𝑖\mathcal{D}^{\prime}_{i} have the same size, and only differ by one sample. 𝒘it+1=ℓ​(𝒟i,𝒘t),superscriptsubscript𝒘𝑖𝑡1ℓsubscript𝒟𝑖superscript𝒘𝑡\boldsymbol{w}_{i}^{t+1}=\ell(\mathcal{D}_{i},\boldsymbol{w}^{t}), (11)

(12)

Assuming that the batch size in the local training is equal to the number of training samples, we have

Δ​ℓΔℓ\displaystyle\Delta\ell =η|𝒟i|​∑m=1|𝒟i|max𝒟i,m,𝒟i,m′∈𝒳∥𝒈i,mt​(𝒟i,m)absentconditional𝜂subscript𝒟𝑖superscriptsubscript𝑚1subscript𝒟𝑖subscriptsubscript𝒟𝑖𝑚subscriptsuperscript𝒟′𝑖𝑚𝒳subscriptsuperscript𝒈𝑡𝑖𝑚subscript𝒟𝑖𝑚\displaystyle=\frac{\eta}{|\mathcal{D}_{i}|}\sum_{m=1}^{|\mathcal{D}_{i}|}\max\limits_{\mathcal{D}_{i,m},\mathcal{D}^{\prime}_{i,m}\in\mathcal{X}}\left\|\boldsymbol{g}^{t}_{i,m}(\mathcal{D}_{i,m})\right. −𝒈i,mt(𝒟i,m′)∥≤2​η​C|𝒟i|,\displaystyle\quad\left.-\boldsymbol{g}^{t}_{i,m}(\mathcal{D}^{\prime}_{i,m})\right\|\leq\frac{2\eta C}{|\mathcal{D}_{i}|},

where C𝐶C is the clipping threshold to bound ‖𝒈i,mt‖normsubscriptsuperscript𝒈𝑡𝑖𝑚\|\boldsymbol{g}^{t}_{i,m}\|.

Then, we need to calculate the privacy loss using the moments account method. Hence, the λ𝜆\lambda-th moment α​(λn)𝛼subscript𝜆𝑛\alpha(\lambda_{n}) can be expressed as (6). We use the above moments and have

αT​(λ)≤∑t=1Tα​(λ,σi)=T​q​λ​(λ+1)​Δ​ℓ22​σi2.superscript𝛼𝑇𝜆superscriptsubscript𝑡1𝑇𝛼𝜆subscript𝜎𝑖𝑇𝑞𝜆𝜆1Δsuperscriptℓ22superscriptsubscript𝜎𝑖2\alpha^{T}(\lambda)\leq\sum_{t=1}^{T}\alpha(\lambda,\sigma_{i})=\frac{Tq\lambda(\lambda+1)\Delta\ell^{2}}{2\sigma_{i}^{2}}. (16)

Using the tail bound by moments [3], we have

δi=minλ⁡exp⁡(T​q​λ​(λ+1)​Δ​ℓ22​σi2−λ​ϵi).subscript𝛿𝑖subscript𝜆𝑇𝑞𝜆𝜆1Δsuperscriptℓ22superscriptsubscript𝜎𝑖2𝜆subscriptitalic-ϵ𝑖\displaystyle\delta_{i}=\min_{\lambda}\exp\left(\frac{Tq\lambda(\lambda+1)\Delta\ell^{2}}{2\sigma_{i}^{2}}-\lambda\epsilon_{i}\right). (17)

Considering inequation (17), we know

T​q​λ​(λ+1)​Δ​ℓ22​σi2−λ​ϵi=T​q​Δ​ℓ22​σi2​(λ+12−ϵi​σi2T​q​Δ​ℓ2)2−T​q​Δ​s22​σi2​(12−ϵi​σi2T​q​Δ​ℓ2)2.𝑇𝑞𝜆𝜆1Δsuperscriptℓ22superscriptsubscript𝜎𝑖2𝜆subscriptitalic-ϵ𝑖𝑇𝑞Δsuperscriptℓ22superscriptsubscript𝜎𝑖2superscript𝜆12subscriptitalic-ϵ𝑖superscriptsubscript𝜎𝑖2𝑇𝑞Δsuperscriptℓ22𝑇𝑞Δsuperscript𝑠22superscriptsubscript𝜎𝑖2superscript12subscriptitalic-ϵ𝑖superscriptsubscript𝜎𝑖2𝑇𝑞Δsuperscriptℓ22\frac{Tq\lambda(\lambda+1)\Delta\ell^{2}}{2\sigma_{i}^{2}}-\lambda\epsilon_{i}=\frac{Tq\Delta\ell^{2}}{2\sigma_{i}^{2}}\left(\lambda+\frac{1}{2}-\frac{\epsilon_{i}\sigma_{i}^{2}}{Tq\Delta\ell^{2}}\right)^{2}\\ -\frac{Tq\Delta s^{2}}{2\sigma_{i}^{2}}\left(\frac{1}{2}-\frac{\epsilon_{i}\sigma_{i}^{2}}{Tq\Delta\ell^{2}}\right)^{2}. (18)

When setting λ=ϵi​σi2T​q​Δ​ℓ2−12𝜆subscriptitalic-ϵ𝑖superscriptsubscript𝜎𝑖2𝑇𝑞Δsuperscriptℓ212\lambda=\frac{\epsilon_{i}\sigma_{i}^{2}}{Tq\Delta\ell^{2}}-\frac{1}{2}, we have

ln⁡(1δi)1subscript𝛿𝑖\displaystyle\ln\left(\frac{1}{\delta_{i}}\right) ≤T​q​Δ​ℓ22​σi2​(12−ϵi​σi2T​q​Δ​ℓ2)2absent𝑇𝑞Δsuperscriptℓ22superscriptsubscript𝜎𝑖2superscript12subscriptitalic-ϵ𝑖superscriptsubscript𝜎𝑖2𝑇𝑞Δsuperscriptℓ22\displaystyle\leq\frac{Tq\Delta\ell^{2}}{2\sigma_{i}^{2}}\left(\frac{1}{2}-\frac{\epsilon_{i}\sigma_{i}^{2}}{Tq\Delta\ell^{2}}\right)^{2} (19)
=T​q​Δ​ℓ28​σi2−ϵi2+ϵi2​σi22​T​q​Δ​ℓ2.absent𝑇𝑞Δsuperscriptℓ28superscriptsubscript𝜎𝑖2subscriptitalic-ϵ𝑖2superscriptsubscriptitalic-ϵ𝑖2superscriptsubscript𝜎𝑖22𝑇𝑞Δsuperscriptℓ2\displaystyle=\frac{Tq\Delta\ell^{2}}{8\sigma_{i}^{2}}-\frac{\epsilon_{i}}{2}+\frac{\epsilon_{i}^{2}\sigma_{i}^{2}}{2Tq\Delta\ell^{2}}.

Since δi∈(0,1)subscript𝛿𝑖01\delta_{i}\in(0,1), we can obtain

T​q​λ​(λ+1)​Δ​ℓ22​σi2−λ​ϵi<0.𝑇𝑞𝜆𝜆1Δsuperscriptℓ22superscriptsubscript𝜎𝑖2𝜆subscriptitalic-ϵ𝑖0\frac{Tq\lambda(\lambda+1)\Delta\ell^{2}}{2\sigma_{i}^{2}}-\lambda\epsilon_{i}<0. (20)

Combine inequation (20), we can bound ln⁡(1/δ)1𝛿\ln\left(1/\delta\right) as

ln⁡(1δi)<−ϵi4+ϵi2​σi22​T​q​Δ​ℓ2<ϵi2​σi22​T​q​Δ​ℓ2.1subscript𝛿𝑖subscriptitalic-ϵ𝑖4superscriptsubscriptitalic-ϵ𝑖2superscriptsubscript𝜎𝑖22𝑇𝑞Δsuperscriptℓ2superscriptsubscriptitalic-ϵ𝑖2superscriptsubscript𝜎𝑖22𝑇𝑞Δsuperscriptℓ2\ln\left(\frac{1}{\delta_{i}}\right)<-\frac{\epsilon_{i}}{4}+\frac{\epsilon_{i}^{2}\sigma_{i}^{2}}{2Tq\Delta\ell^{2}}<\frac{\epsilon_{i}^{2}\sigma_{i}^{2}}{2Tq\Delta\ell^{2}}. (21)

Therefore, we can choose σisubscript𝜎𝑖\sigma_{i} satisfies (10) to guarantee (ϵi,δi)subscriptitalic-ϵ𝑖subscript𝛿𝑖(\epsilon_{i},\delta_{i})-DP in the FL framework. ∎

Theorem 1 quantifies the relation between the noise level σisubscript𝜎𝑖\sigma_{i} and the privacy level ϵisubscriptitalic-ϵ𝑖\epsilon_{i}. It shows that for a fixed perturbation σisubscript𝜎𝑖\sigma_{i} on model parameters, a larger q𝑞q leads to a weaker privacy guarantee (i.e., a larger q/ϵi𝑞subscriptitalic-ϵ𝑖\sqrt{q}/\epsilon_{i}). This is indeed true since when more MTs are involved in computing 𝒘𝒘\boldsymbol{w} at each communication round, there will be a larger probability of information leakage for each MT. Also, for a given ϵisubscriptitalic-ϵ𝑖\epsilon_{i}, a larger T𝑇T in the total training process lead to a higher chance of information leakage because the observer may obtain more information for training datasets. Furthermore, for a given privacy protection level ϵisubscriptitalic-ϵ𝑖\epsilon_{i} and T𝑇T, a larger value of q𝑞q leads to a larger value of σisubscript𝜎𝑖\sigma_{i}, which helps reduce the i𝑖i-th MT concerns on participating in FL because the i𝑖i-th MT are allowed to add more noise to the trained local models. This requires us to choose the parameters carefully in order to have a reasonable privacy level.

4 Discounting Method in UDP

In this section, we first introduce the property that there exists an optimal number of communication rounds in the UDP algorithm. Based on this property, we propose a CRD method to improve convergence performance in the training process. Then, we provide a noise calculation method for obtaining the STD of the additive noises in the case of varying T𝑇T during the FL training. Finally, we will summarize our proposed CRD algorithm.

4.1 Performance Analysis for UDP

First, we start with the essential assumption of on the global loss function F​(⋅)𝐹⋅F(\cdot) defined by F​(⋅)≜∑i=1Upi​Fi​(⋅)≜𝐹⋅superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑈subscript𝑝𝑖subscript𝐹𝑖⋅F(\cdot)\triangleq\sum_{i=1}^{U}p_{i}F_{i}(\cdot), and the i𝑖i-th local loss function Fi​(⋅)subscript𝐹𝑖⋅F_{i}(\cdot) for the analysis, which can be satisfied normally.

Assumption 1

We assume the following conditions for the loss function of all MTs:

  1. 1)

    Fi​(𝒘)subscript𝐹𝑖𝒘F_{i}(\boldsymbol{w}) is convex;

  2. 2)

    Fi​(𝒘)subscript𝐹𝑖𝒘F_{i}(\boldsymbol{w}) satisfies the Polyak-Lojasiewicz condition with the positive parameter μ𝜇\mu, which implies that F​(𝒘)−F​(𝒘∗)≤12​μ​‖∇F​(𝒘)‖2𝐹𝒘𝐹superscript𝒘12𝜇superscriptnorm∇𝐹𝒘2F(\boldsymbol{w})-F(\boldsymbol{w}^{*})\leq\frac{1}{2\mu}\|\nabla F(\boldsymbol{w})\|^{2}, where 𝒘∗superscript𝒘\boldsymbol{w}^{*} is the optimal result;

  3. 3)

    Fi​(𝒘)subscript𝐹𝑖𝒘F_{i}(\boldsymbol{w}) is L𝐿L-Lipschitz smooth, i.e., for any 𝒘𝒘\boldsymbol{w}, 𝒘′superscript𝒘′\boldsymbol{w}^{\prime}, ‖∇Fi​(𝒘)−∇Fi​(𝒘′)‖≤L​‖𝒘−𝒘′‖norm∇subscript𝐹𝑖𝒘∇subscript𝐹𝑖superscript𝒘′𝐿norm𝒘superscript𝒘′\|\nabla F_{i}(\boldsymbol{w})-\nabla F_{i}(\boldsymbol{w}^{\prime})\|\leq L\|\boldsymbol{w}-\boldsymbol{w}^{\prime}\|, where L𝐿L is a constant determined by the practical loss function;

  4. 4)

    η≤1L𝜂1𝐿\eta\leq\frac{1}{L}, where η𝜂\eta is the learning rate;

  5. 5)

    For any i𝑖i and 𝒘𝒘\boldsymbol{w}, ‖∇Fi​(𝒘)−∇F​(𝒘)‖≤εinorm∇subscript𝐹𝑖𝒘∇𝐹𝒘subscript𝜀𝑖\|\nabla F_{i}(\boldsymbol{w})-\nabla F(\boldsymbol{w})\|\leq\varepsilon_{i} and 𝔼​{εi}=ε𝔼subscript𝜀𝑖𝜀\mathbb{E}\{\varepsilon_{i}\}=\varepsilon, where εisubscript𝜀𝑖\varepsilon_{i} is the divergence metric.

Based on the above assumptions and Theorem 1, we can obtain the following result which characterizes the convergence performance of the UDP algorithm.

Theorem 2

To guarantee (ϵi,δi)subscriptitalic-ϵ𝑖subscript𝛿𝑖(\epsilon_{i},\delta_{i})-DP for all MTs, the convergence upper bound of the UDP algorithm after T𝑇T communication rounds is given by

𝔼​{F​(𝒘T)}−F​(𝒘∗)≤AT​(F​(𝒘0)−F​(𝒘∗))+(1−AT)​(κ0​T​KU2​∑i=1Uln⁡(1/δi)ϵi2+κ1​U​(U−K)K​(U−1)),𝔼𝐹superscript𝒘𝑇𝐹superscript𝒘superscript𝐴𝑇𝐹superscript𝒘0𝐹superscript𝒘1superscript𝐴𝑇subscript𝜅0𝑇𝐾superscript𝑈2superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑈1subscript𝛿𝑖superscriptsubscriptitalic-ϵ𝑖2subscript𝜅1𝑈𝑈𝐾𝐾𝑈1\mathbb{E}\{F(\boldsymbol{w}^{T})\}-F(\boldsymbol{w}^{*})\leq A^{T}(F(\boldsymbol{w}^{0})-F(\boldsymbol{w}^{*}))\\ +(1-A^{T})\left(\frac{\kappa_{0}TK}{U^{2}}\sum_{i=1}^{U}\frac{\ln(1/\delta_{i})}{\epsilon_{i}^{2}}+\frac{\kappa_{1}U(U-K)}{K(U-1)}\right), (22)

where A=1−2​μ​η+μ​η2​L𝐴12𝜇𝜂𝜇superscript𝜂2𝐿A=1-2\mu\eta+\mu\eta^{2}L, κ0=L2​Δ​ℓ2μsubscript𝜅0superscript𝐿2Δsuperscriptℓ2𝜇\kappa_{0}=\frac{L^{2}\Delta\ell^{2}}{\mu} and κ1=η2​L2​ε2​μsubscript𝜅1superscript𝜂2superscript𝐿2𝜀2𝜇\kappa_{1}=\frac{\eta^{2}L^{2}\varepsilon}{2\mu}.

Proof:

See Appendix  B. ∎

From Theorem 2, we can find an explicit tradeoff between convergence performance and privacy: When privacy guarantee is weak (large values of ϵisubscriptitalic-ϵ𝑖\epsilon_{i} and δisubscript𝛿𝑖\delta_{i}, and small values of ∑i=1Uln⁡(1/δi)ϵi2superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑈1subscript𝛿𝑖superscriptsubscriptitalic-ϵ𝑖2\sum_{i=1}^{U}\frac{\ln(1/\delta_{i})}{\epsilon_{i}^{2}}), the convergence bound will be small, which indicates a tight convergence to the optimal weights. From our assumptions, we know that η​L≤1𝜂𝐿1\eta L\leq 1 and obtain A<1𝐴1A<1. Then, we show the process on discovering the relationship between the convergence upper bound and the number of total MTs U𝑈U, the number of participant MTs K𝐾K and the number of communication rounds T𝑇T. We find that the number of communication rounds T𝑇T is a key factor, and then obtain the following theorem.

Theorem 3

There exists an optimal number of communication rounds to achieve the best learning performance for the given ϵisubscriptitalic-ϵ𝑖\epsilon_{i}, ∀i∈𝒰for-all𝑖𝒰\forall i\in\mathcal{U}, and a sufficiently large U𝑈U.

Proof:

With a slight abuse of notation, we consider continuous values of U≥1𝑈1U\geq 1, 1≤K≤U1𝐾𝑈1\leq K\leq U and T≥1𝑇1T\geq 1. Let h​(U,K,T)ℎ𝑈𝐾𝑇h(U,K,T) denote the right hand side (RHS) of (59) and we have

∂2h​(U,K,T,ϵi)∂T2=ATln2A(F(𝒘0)−F(𝒘∗)−κ0​T​KU2∑i=1Uln⁡(1/δi)ϵi2−κ1​(U−K)K​(U−1)−κ0​T​KU​ln⁡A∑i=1Uln⁡(1/δi)ϵi2).superscript2ℎ𝑈𝐾𝑇subscriptitalic-ϵ𝑖superscript𝑇2superscript𝐴𝑇superscript2𝐴𝐹superscript𝒘0𝐹superscript𝒘subscript𝜅0𝑇𝐾superscript𝑈2superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑈1subscript𝛿𝑖superscriptsubscriptitalic-ϵ𝑖2subscript𝜅1𝑈𝐾𝐾𝑈1subscript𝜅0𝑇𝐾𝑈𝐴superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑈1subscript𝛿𝑖superscriptsubscriptitalic-ϵ𝑖2\frac{\partial^{2}h(U,K,T,\epsilon_{i})}{\partial T^{2}}=A^{T}\ln^{2}{A}\bigg{(}F(\boldsymbol{w}^{0})-F(\boldsymbol{w}^{*})\\ -\frac{\kappa_{0}TK}{U^{2}}\sum_{i=1}^{U}\frac{\ln(1/\delta_{i})}{\epsilon_{i}^{2}}-\frac{\kappa_{1}(U-K)}{K(U-1)}-\frac{\kappa_{0}TK}{U\ln{A}}\sum_{i=1}^{U}\frac{\ln(1/\delta_{i})}{\epsilon_{i}^{2}}\bigg{)}. (23)

It can be seen that the first term and fourth term of on the RHS of (23) are always positive. When U𝑈U and K𝐾K are set to be large enough, and ∑i=1Uln⁡(1/δi)ϵi2superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑈1subscript𝛿𝑖superscriptsubscriptitalic-ϵ𝑖2\sum_{i=1}^{U}\frac{\ln(1/\delta_{i})}{\epsilon_{i}^{2}} is small (proper privacy guarantee), we can see that the second term of on the RHS of (23) is small. In this case, we have ∂2h​(U,T,ϵi)∂T2>0superscript2ℎ𝑈𝑇subscriptitalic-ϵ𝑖superscript𝑇20\frac{\partial^{2}h(U,T,\epsilon_{i})}{\partial T^{2}}>0 and the upper bound is convex for T𝑇T.

Then we consider the condition K=U𝐾𝑈K=U, we have

∂2h​(U,T,ϵi)∂T2=ATln2A(F(𝒘0)−F(𝒘∗)−κ0​TU∑i=1Uln⁡(1/δi)ϵi2−κ0​TU​ln⁡A∑i=1Uln⁡(1/δi)ϵi2).superscript2ℎ𝑈𝑇subscriptitalic-ϵ𝑖superscript𝑇2superscript𝐴𝑇superscript2𝐴𝐹superscript𝒘0𝐹superscript𝒘subscript𝜅0𝑇𝑈superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑈1subscript𝛿𝑖superscriptsubscriptitalic-ϵ𝑖2subscript𝜅0𝑇𝑈𝐴superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑈1subscript𝛿𝑖superscriptsubscriptitalic-ϵ𝑖2\frac{\partial^{2}h(U,T,\epsilon_{i})}{\partial T^{2}}=A^{T}\ln^{2}{A}\bigg{(}F(\boldsymbol{w}^{0})-F(\boldsymbol{w}^{*})\\ -\frac{\kappa_{0}T}{U}\sum_{i=1}^{U}\frac{\ln(1/\delta_{i})}{\epsilon_{i}^{2}}-\frac{\kappa_{0}T}{U\ln{A}}\sum_{i=1}^{U}\frac{\ln(1/\delta_{i})}{\epsilon_{i}^{2}}\bigg{)}. (24)

If U𝑈U is set to be large enough, and ∑i=1Uln⁡(1/δi)ϵi2superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑈1subscript𝛿𝑖superscriptsubscriptitalic-ϵ𝑖2\sum_{i=1}^{U}\frac{\ln(1/\delta_{i})}{\epsilon_{i}^{2}} is small, we have ∂2h​(U,T,ϵi)∂T2>0superscript2ℎ𝑈𝑇subscriptitalic-ϵ𝑖superscript𝑇20\frac{\partial^{2}h(U,T,\epsilon_{i})}{\partial T^{2}}>0 and the upper bound is convex for T𝑇T. ∎

In more detail, a larger T𝑇T has a negative impact on the model quality by increasing the amount of noise added in each communication round for a given ϵisubscriptitalic-ϵ𝑖\epsilon_{i}, ∀i∈𝒰for-all𝑖𝒰\forall i\in\mathcal{U} (in line with (59)), but it also has a positive impact on the convergence because it reduces the loss function value with more iterations.

According to our analysis above, there exists an optimal value of T𝑇T for given privacy levels ϵisubscriptitalic-ϵ𝑖\epsilon_{i}, ∀i∈𝒰for-all𝑖𝒰\forall i\in\mathcal{U}. However, this optimal value cannot be derived directly, since some parameters of the loss function are difficult to obtain accurately. One possible method for obtaining the optimal T𝑇T is through exhaustive search, i.e., try different value of T𝑇T and choose the one with the highest convergence performance as the practical value in use. The time complexity of the exhaustive search method is determined by the searching interval and a smaller interval means a larger complexity but a higher performance. Hence, exhaustive search is time-consuming and computationally complex. In the next section, we will propose an efficient algorithm for finding a good value of T𝑇T to achieve a high convergence performance.

4.2 Proposed Discounting Communication Rounds

Based on the analysis above, we can note that an improper value of T𝑇T will damage the performance of the UDP algorithm. Hence, if we reduce the value of T𝑇T slightly when the training performance stops improving, we can obtain a smaller STD as well as improving the training performance. Therefore, we design a CRD algorithm by adjusting the number of communication rounds T𝑇T with a discounting method during the training process to achieve a better convergence performance. The training process of such a CRD algorithm in UDP contains following steps:

  • ∙∙\bullet

    Initialization: The server broadcasts the initial parameters (i.e., 𝒘0superscript𝒘0\boldsymbol{w}^{0} and T𝑇T) to all MTs;

  • ∙∙\bullet

    Step 1: Local training: All active MTs locally compute training parameters with local datasets and the global parameter. In order to prove the DP guarantee, the influence of each individual example on local gradients should be bounded with a clipping threshold C𝐶C. Each gradient vector will be clipped in L2subscript𝐿2L_{2} norm, i.e., the i𝑖i-th local gradient vector 𝒈itsuperscriptsubscript𝒈𝑖𝑡\boldsymbol{g}_{i}^{t} at the t𝑡t-th communication round is replaced by 𝒈it/max⁡(1,‖𝒈itC‖)superscriptsubscript𝒈𝑖𝑡1normsuperscriptsubscript𝒈𝑖𝑡𝐶\boldsymbol{g}_{i}^{t}/\max(1,\|\frac{\boldsymbol{g}_{i}^{t}}{C}\|). We can remark that parameter clipping of this form is a popular ingredient of ML for non-privacy reasons;

  • ∙∙\bullet

    Step 2: Noise calculation: Each MT obtain the STD σisubscript𝜎𝑖\sigma_{i} of artificial Gaussian noise using the proposed noise calculation method (introduced in the following subsection);

  • ∙∙\bullet

    Step 3: Noise adding: Each MT add artificial Gaussian noise with a certain STD to the local trained parameters in order to guarantee (ϵi,δi)subscriptitalic-ϵ𝑖subscript𝛿𝑖(\epsilon_{i},\delta_{i})-LDP;

  • ∙∙\bullet

    Step 4: Parameter uploading: All active MTs upload the noised parameters to the server for aggregation;

  • ∙∙\bullet

    Step 5: Model aggregation: The server performs aggregation over the uploaded parameters from MTs;

  • ∙∙\bullet

    Step 6: Model broadcasting: The server broadcasts the aggregated parameters and the number of communication rounds T𝑇T to all MTs;

  • ∙∙\bullet

    Step 7: Model updating: All MTs update their respective models with the aggregated parameters, then test the performance of the updated models and upload the performance to the server;

  • ∙∙\bullet

    Step 8: Communication rounds discounting: When the convergence performance stops improving by the following decision 𝒱​(𝒘t)−𝒱​(𝒘t+1)<ζ𝒱superscript𝒘𝑡𝒱superscript𝒘𝑡1𝜁\mathcal{V}(\boldsymbol{w}^{t})-\mathcal{V}(\boldsymbol{w}^{t+1})<\zeta and ζ𝜁\zeta is the threshold, the discounting method will be triggered in the server, where 𝒱​(𝒘t)𝒱superscript𝒘𝑡\mathcal{V}(\boldsymbol{w}^{t}) is the test loss by the model 𝒘tsuperscript𝒘𝑡\boldsymbol{w}^{t}. The server will obtain a smaller T𝑇T than the previous one with a linear discounting factor β𝛽\beta and an integer value by T=⌊β​(T−t)⌋+t𝑇𝛽𝑇𝑡𝑡T=\lfloor\beta(T-t)\rfloor+t. This factor can control the decaying speed of T𝑇T. The FL process will be completed when the aggregation time reaches the preset T𝑇T.

First, we can note that the value of ζ𝜁\zeta will have an impact on the number of communications T𝑇T and not affect the convergence and the privacy guarantee directly. Then, the value of ζ𝜁\zeta is to predict whether the training process is stopping and determine when to trigger the discounting method (adjust the number of communications). In the conventional machine learning, a threshold is common to predict whether the training process is stopping. Therefore, in our experiments, we adopt a small positive value 0.0010.0010.001 as the value of ζ𝜁\zeta. Moreover, in this method, the value of T𝑇T is determined iteratively to ensure a high convergence performance in FL training. Obviously, when the value of T𝑇T is adjusted, we must calculate a new STD of additive noises in terms of previous training process. The diagrammatic expression of this method is shown in Fig. 1. Therefore, we will develop a noise calculation method to update the STD of additive noises and T𝑇T alternately in the following subsection.

4.3 Noise Calculation for Varying T𝑇T

Now, let t𝑡t be the index of the current communication round and σiτsubscriptsuperscript𝜎𝜏𝑖\sigma^{\tau}_{i} (0≤τ≤t−10𝜏𝑡10\leq\tau\leq t-1) be the STD of additive noises for the i𝑖i-th MT at the τ𝜏\tau-th communication round. In our CRD algorithm, with a new T𝑇T, if t𝑡t is greater than T𝑇T, the training process will stop. If t𝑡t is less than T𝑇T, we need to calculate the STD of noises and add them on the local parameters in the following communication round. Considering this, we obtain the following theorem.

Theorem 4

After t𝑡t (0≤t<T0𝑡𝑇0\leq t<T) communication rounds and a new T𝑇T, the STD of additive noises for the i𝑖i-th MT to guarantee (ϵi,δi)subscriptitalic-ϵ𝑖subscript𝛿𝑖(\epsilon_{i},\delta_{i})-LDP can be given as

σit=(T−tϵi22​q​Δ​ℓ2​ln⁡(1δi)−∑τ=0t−11(σiτ)2)12.subscriptsuperscript𝜎𝑡𝑖superscript𝑇𝑡superscriptsubscriptitalic-ϵ𝑖22𝑞Δsuperscriptℓ21subscript𝛿𝑖superscriptsubscript𝜏0𝑡11superscriptsubscriptsuperscript𝜎𝜏𝑖212\sigma^{t}_{i}=\left(\frac{T-t}{\frac{\epsilon_{i}^{2}}{2q\Delta\ell^{2}\ln\left(\frac{1}{\delta_{i}}\right)}-\sum_{\tau=0}^{t-1}\frac{1}{(\sigma^{\tau}_{i})^{2}}}\right)^{\frac{1}{2}}. (25)
Proof:

Using the above definition of moments (16) and a preset value of T𝑇T, we have

(26)

Using the tail bound by moments [3], we have

Because of

Then, we can set (25) to guarantee (ϵi,δi)subscriptitalic-ϵ𝑖subscript𝛿𝑖(\epsilon_{i},\delta_{i})-DP for the following training.

∎

In Theorem 4, we can obtain a proper STD of the additive noises based on the previous training process and the value of T𝑇T. From this result, we can find that if we have large STDs (strong privacy guarantee) in the previous t−1𝑡1t-1 training processes, i.e., σiτsubscriptsuperscript𝜎𝜏𝑖\sigma^{\tau}_{i} is large, the calculated STD will be small (weak privacy guarantee), i.e., σitsubscriptsuperscript𝜎𝑡𝑖\sigma^{t}_{i} is small.

We can also note that if the value of T𝑇T is not changed in this communication round, the value of STD will remain unchanged. Considering σitsubscriptsuperscript𝜎𝑡𝑖\sigma^{t}_{i}, σit+1subscriptsuperscript𝜎𝑡1𝑖\sigma^{t+1}_{i} and unchanged T𝑇T, from equation (25), we can obtain

σit+1=(T−t−1ϵi22​q​Δ​ℓ2​ln⁡(1δi)−∑τ=0t1(σiτ)2)12,subscriptsuperscript𝜎𝑡1𝑖superscript𝑇𝑡1superscriptsubscriptitalic-ϵ𝑖22𝑞Δsuperscriptℓ21subscript𝛿𝑖superscriptsubscript𝜏0𝑡1superscriptsubscriptsuperscript𝜎𝜏𝑖212\sigma^{t+1}_{i}=\left(\frac{T-t-1}{\frac{\epsilon_{i}^{2}}{2q\Delta\ell^{2}\ln\left(\frac{1}{\delta_{i}}\right)}-\sum_{\tau=0}^{t}\frac{1}{(\sigma^{\tau}_{i})^{2}}}\right)^{\frac{1}{2}}, (30)

and

ϵi22​q​Δ​ℓ2​ln⁡(1δi)−∑τ=0t−11(σiτ)2=T−t(σit)2.subscriptsuperscriptitalic-ϵ2𝑖2𝑞Δsuperscriptℓ21subscript𝛿𝑖superscriptsubscript𝜏0𝑡11superscriptsubscriptsuperscript𝜎𝜏𝑖2𝑇𝑡superscriptsubscriptsuperscript𝜎𝑡𝑖2\frac{\epsilon^{2}_{i}}{2q\Delta\ell^{2}\ln\left(\frac{1}{\delta_{i}}\right)}-\sum_{\tau=0}^{t-1}\frac{1}{(\sigma^{\tau}_{i})^{2}}=\frac{T-t}{\left(\sigma^{t}_{i}\right)^{2}}. 4.4 Complexity Analysis

The main difference between the proposed training protocol in Algorithm 1 and the conventional algorithm is the gradients clipping, noise computing and noise adding. During the training process in Algorithm 1, each MT needs to clip the gradients by the equation 𝒈i,mt​(𝒟i,m)=𝒈i,mt​(𝒟i,m)/max⁡(1,‖𝒈i,mt​(𝒟i,m)‖2C)subscriptsuperscript𝒈𝑡𝑖𝑚subscript𝒟𝑖𝑚subscriptsuperscript𝒈𝑡𝑖𝑚subscript𝒟𝑖𝑚1subscriptnormsubscriptsuperscript𝒈𝑡𝑖𝑚subscript𝒟𝑖𝑚2𝐶\boldsymbol{g}^{t}_{i,m}(\mathcal{D}_{i,m})=\boldsymbol{g}^{t}_{i,m}(\mathcal{D}_{i,m})/\max\left(1,\frac{\|\boldsymbol{g}^{t}_{i,m}(\mathcal{D}_{i,m})\|_{2}}{C}\right) locally, which takes O​(s​(𝒘))𝑂𝑠𝒘O(s({\boldsymbol{w}})) time, where s​(𝒘)𝑠𝒘s({\boldsymbol{w}}) is the size of 𝒘𝒘\boldsymbol{w}. We can note that this clipping process will compare the norm of gradients and the clipping threshold C𝐶C to bound the gradients. The noise computing can be expressed as σi=Δ​ℓ​2​q​T​ln⁡(1/δi)ϵisubscript𝜎𝑖Δℓ2𝑞𝑇1subscript𝛿𝑖subscriptitalic-ϵ𝑖\sigma_{i}=\frac{\Delta\ell\sqrt{2qT\ln(1/\delta_{i})}}{\epsilon_{i}} and takes O​(1)𝑂1O(1) time, which can be obtained directly when all required parameters are ready. Finally, the noise adding is given by 𝒘~it+1=𝒘it+1+𝒩​(0,σi2​𝐈)subscriptsuperscriptbold-~𝒘𝑡1𝑖subscriptsuperscript𝒘𝑡1𝑖𝒩0superscriptsubscript𝜎𝑖2𝐈\boldsymbol{\widetilde{w}}^{t+1}_{i}=\boldsymbol{w}^{t+1}_{i}+\mathcal{N}(0,\sigma_{i}^{2}\mathbf{I}), where the complexity is governed by the size of model parameters and is O​(s​(𝒘))𝑂𝑠𝒘O(s({\boldsymbol{w}})).

Meanwhile, Algorithm 2 has improved the noise computing and added the adjusting process for the number of communication rounds (T𝑇T) compared with Algorithm 1. Therefore, the noise computing in Algorithm 2 can be given by σit=(T−t)12/(ϵi22​q​Δ​ℓ2​ln⁡(1δi)−∑τ=0t−11(σiτ)2)12subscriptsuperscript𝜎𝑡𝑖superscript𝑇𝑡12superscriptsubscriptsuperscriptitalic-ϵ2𝑖2𝑞Δsuperscriptℓ21subscript𝛿𝑖superscriptsubscript𝜏0𝑡11superscriptsubscriptsuperscript𝜎𝜏𝑖212\sigma^{t}_{i}=(T-t)^{\frac{1}{2}}/\left(\frac{\epsilon^{2}_{i}}{2q\Delta\ell^{2}\ln(\frac{1}{\delta_{i}})}-\sum\limits_{\tau=0}^{t-1}\frac{1}{(\sigma^{\tau}_{i})^{2}}\right)^{\frac{1}{2}} and obtained directly when all required parameters are ready. Moreover, the adjusting process for the number of communication rounds T𝑇T only needs few computing resources. Both processes only need O​(1)𝑂1O(1) time.

In summary, the time complexity analysis of the proposed training protocols, i.e., Algorithm 1 and Algorithm 2, is O​(s​(𝒘))𝑂𝑠𝒘O(s({\boldsymbol{w}})). Furthermore, the proposed training protocols consume few more computing resources.

5 Experimental Results

In this section, we evaluate the accuracy of our analytical results for different learning tasks. Then, we evaluate our proposed CRD method in UDP algorithm, and demonstrate the effectiveness of various parameter settings, such as the privacy level, the initial value of T𝑇T and discounting factor.

5.1 Evaluation of Numerical Results

In this subsection, we first describe our numerical validation of the bound compared with the real value in (15) with σi=0.01subscript𝜎𝑖0.01\sigma_{i}=0.01 by varying λ𝜆\lambda from 111 to 100100100. In Fig. 2 (a), we set q=0.9𝑞0.9q=0.9, |𝒟i|=800subscript𝒟𝑖800|\mathcal{D}_{i}|=800, ∀ifor-all𝑖\forall i, and U=50𝑈50U=50. In our validation, our bound is close but always higher than the real divergence. We also did tests for cases such as a smaller sampling ratio q=0.1𝑞0.1q=0.1, a smaller size of local datasets |𝒟i|=400subscript𝒟𝑖400|\mathcal{D}_{i}|=400, ∀ifor-all𝑖\forall i, and a larger number of MTs U=200𝑈200U=200 in Fig. 2 (b), (c) and (d), respectively. We find that the empirical bound always holds and closes under the given conditions, especially for a large enough |𝒟i|subscript𝒟𝑖|\mathcal{D}_{i}|. Therefore, we have the conjecture that our bound is a valid for the analytical moments accountant of sampled Gaussian mechanism and seek its formal proof in our future work.

5.2 Experimentation Setup

We evaluate the training of three different machine learning models on different datasets, namely support vector machine (SVM) on the IPUMS-US dataset, multi-layer perceptron (MLP) on the standard MNIST dataset and the convolutional neural network (CNN) on the CIFAR-10 dataset, respectively.

Models and Datasets Description. The models include SVM, MLP and CNN, which are detailed as follows.

1) SVM is trained on the IPUMS-US dataset, which are census data extracted from [18] and contain 400004000040000 individual records with 585858 attributes including age, education level and so on. The categorical attributes in the dataset are denoted by various integers. The label of each sample describes whether the annual income of this individual is over 252525k. In this model, the loss function is given by

F​(𝒘)=κ2​‖𝒘‖22+max⁡{ym−𝒘⊤​𝒟i,m,0},𝐹𝒘𝜅2subscriptsuperscriptnorm𝒘22subscript𝑦𝑚superscript𝒘topsubscript𝒟𝑖𝑚0F(\boldsymbol{w})=\frac{\kappa}{2}\|\boldsymbol{w}\|^{2}_{2}+\max\{y_{m}-\boldsymbol{w}^{\top}\mathcal{D}_{i,m},0\}, (32)

where κ>0𝜅0\kappa>0 is a regularization coefficient, 𝒟i,msubscript𝒟𝑖𝑚\mathcal{D}_{i,m} is the m𝑚m-th sample in 𝒟isubscript𝒟𝑖\mathcal{D}_{i}, 𝒟isubscript𝒟𝑖\mathcal{D}_{i} is the dataset of i𝑖i-th MT and ym∈{+1,−1}subscript𝑦𝑚11y_{m}\in\{+1,-1\} for m∈{1,…,|𝒟i|}𝑚1…subscript𝒟𝑖m\in\{1,\ldots,|\mathcal{D}_{i}|\}.

2) MLP is trained using SGD consisting of single hidden layer with 256256256 hidden units, where ReLU units and softmax of 101010 classes (corresponding to the 101010 digits) are applied. We use the cross-entropy loss function and conduct experiments on the standard MNIST dataset for handwritten digit recognition consisting of 600006000060000 training examples and 100001000010000 testing examples [28]. Each example is a 28×28282828\times 28 size gray-level image of handwritten digits from 00 to 101010. In Fig. 3, we show several samples of the standard MNIST dataset with a visual illustration via MLP. The left figure and right figure in Fig. 3 are derived from the original FL model and UDP model, respectively. The visual results of MLP based FL with the interpretability technique are corresponding to the digit 0∼9similar-to090\sim 9 under the original FL and UDP based FL, respectively. Basically speaking, these subfigures show that a digit understood by the machine model with the original FL are more distinct than the UDP based FL.

3) CNN is trained using SGD consisting of single convolutional layer with the convolutional kernel size 555 and the padding size 444, where ReLU units and softmax of 101010 classes are applied. We also use the cross-entropy loss function in this model. The CIFA-101010 dataset consists of 32×32323232\times 32 color images with three channels (RGB) in 101010 classes including ships, planes, dogs and cats. Each class has 600060006000 images where there are 400004000040000 examples for training, 100001000010000 for testing and 100001000010000 for validation.

Among them, the loss function for SVM is convex, whereas the loss function for MLP does not satisfy this condition. The experimental results in this setting show that our theoretical results and proposed algorithm also work well for models (such as MLP) whose loss functions are not convex.

Parameter Setting. The total number of MTs U𝑈U in our experiments is set to 505050. In order to conduct our experiments conveniently, we consider the worst condition for model convergence with ϵi=ϵpsubscriptitalic-ϵ𝑖subscriptitalic-ϵp\epsilon_{i}=\epsilon_{\text{p}} and δi=δpsubscript𝛿𝑖subscript𝛿p\delta_{i}=\delta_{\text{p}}, ∀i∈𝒰for-all𝑖𝒰\forall i\in\mathcal{U}, where ϵpsubscriptitalic-ϵp\epsilon_{\text{p}} and δpsubscript𝛿p\delta_{\text{p}} are the smallest values of permitting. In addition, we adopt a certain δ𝛿\delta to study the effect of ϵpsubscriptitalic-ϵp\epsilon_{\text{p}} and set δp=0.001subscript𝛿p0.001\delta_{\text{p}}=0.001. The threshold ζ𝜁\zeta in CRD method is set to 0.0010.0010.001. We can note that parameter clipping C𝐶C is a popular ingredient of SGD and ML for non-privacy reasons. A proper value of clipping threshold C𝐶C should be considered for the DP based FL framework. In the following experiments, we utilize the method in [29] and choose C𝐶C by taking the median of the norms of the unclipped parameters over the course of training.

5.3 Effects of the number of Communication Rounds on UDP

In this subsection, we verify the convex property of UDP for the value of T𝑇T with SVM and MLP models. In Fig. 4, we show experimental results of testing loss as a function of T𝑇T with various privacy levels using SVM. The size of local samples is set as |𝒟i|=128subscript𝒟𝑖128|\mathcal{D}_{i}|=128. The observation is in line with Theorem 2 and  3, and the reason comes from the fact that a lower privacy level decreases the standard deviation of additive noises and the server can obtain better quality ML model parameters from MTs. Fig. 4 also implies that an optimal value of T𝑇T increases with a larger ϵpsubscriptitalic-ϵp\epsilon_{\text{p}}.

Then, we show experimental results of the loss function value with respect to T𝑇T and privacy levels ϵpsubscriptitalic-ϵp\epsilon_{\text{p}} using the MLP network. The size of local samples is set as |𝒟i|=800subscript𝒟𝑖800|\mathcal{D}_{i}|=800 in this experiment. Figs. 5 and 6 illustrate the expectation of the loss function, by varying privacy level ϵpsubscriptitalic-ϵp\epsilon_{\text{p}} and the value of T𝑇T. From Fig. 5, we can observe that a large T𝑇T and a small ϵpsubscriptitalic-ϵp\epsilon_{\text{p}} may lead to a worse performance in the no sampling scenario. As shown in the second scenario with sampling ratio q=0.6𝑞0.6q=0.6 in Fig. 6, it also retains the same property.

5.4 Effects of Parameters on CRD

In this subsection, to evaluate our CRD algorithm, we apply the MLP model with the standard MNIST dataset. Several experimental settings in our case study are introduced as follows. The setting including the following main parts: 1) various initial values of T𝑇T using discounting method; 2) various privacy levels using CRD algorithm; and 3) various discounting factors using CRD algorithm.

We evaluate the effectiveness of our CRD method, and compare the results with the following benchmarks: 1) original UDP, in which uniform privacy budget (ϵpsubscriptitalic-ϵp\epsilon_{\text{p}}) allocation algorithm as well as the moments accountant method [3] is adopted in the UDP algorithm; 2) Lei’s approach [29] in which the STD of added noise will be reduced linearly until the privacy loss is lager than a preset ϵpsubscriptitalic-ϵp\epsilon_{\text{p}}; and 3) optimal UDP, in which the UDP algorithm will be trained with the optimal T𝑇T (obtained by heuristic search).

Initial Value of T𝑇T. In the previous experiments, the initial value of T𝑇T is set as the default. To examine the effect of initial T𝑇T, we vary its value from 150150150 to 300300300 and measure the model convergence performance under several fixed privacy levels. We also choose this handwritten digit recognition task with the size of local samples |𝒟i|=800subscript𝒟𝑖800|\mathcal{D}_{i}|=800 and the discounting factor β=0.9𝛽0.9\beta=0.9. Fig. 7 shows that when T𝑇T is closer to the optimal value of T𝑇T (the optimal value of T𝑇T by searching is shown in the above subsection), we can obtain a better convergence performance. This observation is also in line with Theorem 2 and  3.

Privacy Level. We choose a handwritten digit recognition task with the initial number of communication rounds T=200𝑇200T=200 and the size of local samples |𝒟i|=800subscript𝒟𝑖800|\mathcal{D}_{i}|=800. We also set two different sampling ratio q=1𝑞1q=1 and q=0.6𝑞0.6q=0.6, which are corresponding to Fig. 8, observed by (a) and (b), respectively. In Fig. 8, we describe how value of the loss function change with various values of the privacy level ϵpsubscriptitalic-ϵp\epsilon_{\text{p}} under original UDP (Algorithm 1), UDP with CRD (Algorithm 2) and optimal CRD (obtain the optimal T𝑇T by searching). Fig. 9 shows the test accuracy corresponding to Fig. 8. We can note that using Algorithm 2 with discounting factor β=0.9𝛽0.9\beta=0.9 can greatly improve the convergence performance in Fig. 8 (a) and (b), which is close to the optimal results. Moreover, our UDP with CRD has a better performance than the optimal results with a large ϵpsubscriptitalic-ϵp\epsilon_{\text{p}}, because the UDP algorithm with the optimal T𝑇T (obtained by searching) averagely allocates the privacy budget (ϵpsubscriptitalic-ϵp\epsilon_{\text{p}}) during the training process but our algorithm can utilize the privacy budget more adaptively and efficiently. In Fig. 10, we choose the same parameters with Fig. 8 and show the change of T𝑇T during training in one experiment under the UDP algorithm with CRD method (β=0.9𝛽0.9\beta=0.9). In Fig. 10, we can find that a smaller privacy level ϵpsubscriptitalic-ϵp\epsilon_{\text{p}} will have an early end in UDP algorithm with CRD method. The intuition is that a larger T𝑇T can lead to a higher chance of information leakage and a larger noise STD of additive noises. Then, the CRD method may be triggered and a decreased T𝑇T will be broadcasted to chosen MTs from the server.

In Fig. 11, we evaluate a CNN based federated learning for the multi-class classification task with the dataset CIFAR-10 in UDP with CRD, where each client has 800800800 training samples locally. The protection levels are set to ϵ=4italic-ϵ4\epsilon=4, ϵ=8italic-ϵ8\epsilon=8, ϵ=12italic-ϵ12\epsilon=12, ϵ=16italic-ϵ16\epsilon=16 and ϵ=20italic-ϵ20\epsilon=20 for this experiment. In addition, we set N=50𝑁50N=50, K=30𝐾30K=30, T=200𝑇200T=200 and β=0.9𝛽0.9\beta=0.9. From Fig. 11, comparing with the original UDP and Lei’s approach, we can note that using Algorithm 2 with discounting factor β=0.9𝛽0.9\beta=0.9 can greatly improve the convergence performance.

We also apply the MLP model with the standard MNIST dataset with the settings of non-IID data distribution and different number of samples (unbalanced) in UDP with CRD, For the non-IID data distribution setting, each MT has four kinds of digits with the same amount, and the variety is different from all other MTs. In the unbalanced setting, all MTs are divided into 555 parts and the MT in each part has different number of training samples (400, 600, 800, 1000 and 1200, respectively ) locally. The protection levels are set to ϵ=4italic-ϵ4\epsilon=4, ϵ=8italic-ϵ8\epsilon=8, ϵ=12italic-ϵ12\epsilon=12, ϵ=16italic-ϵ16\epsilon=16 and ϵ=20italic-ϵ20\epsilon=20 for this experiment. In addition, we set N=K=50𝑁𝐾50N=K=50, T=200𝑇200T=200 and β=0.9𝛽0.9\beta=0.9 From Figs. 12 and 13, we can note that using Algorithm 2 with discounting factor β=0.9𝛽0.9\beta=0.9 can greatly improve the test accuracy comparing with the original UDP and Lei’s approach.

Discounting Factor. In Fig. 14, we vary the value of β𝛽\beta from 0.50.50.5 to 0.90.90.9 and plot their convergence results of the loss function. The size of local samples and the initial number of communication rounds are set as |𝒟i|=800subscript𝒟𝑖800|\mathcal{D}_{i}|=800 and T=200𝑇200T=200, respectively. We observe that when the privacy level is fixed, a larger β𝛽\beta results in a slower decay speed of the T𝑇T which means careful adjustments of T𝑇T in the training and will benefit the convergence performance. This is consistent with Theorem 2 and  3. With various values of different β𝛽\beta, when we choose β=0.8𝛽0.8\beta=0.8, the UDP algorithm with CRD method will have the best convergence performance. In Fig. 15, we show the communication rounds consuming (the number of required communication rounds) with various discounting factors using the same parameters with Fig. 14. We find that more careful adjustments (corresponding to a larger β𝛽\beta) will lead to more communication rounds consuming. Hence, we can conclude that there is a tradeoff between communication rounds consuming and convergence performance by choosing β𝛽\beta. As a future work, it is of great interest to analytically evaluate the optimum value of β𝛽\beta to minimize the loss function.

6 Conclusion

In this paper, we have introduced a UDP algorithm in FL to preserve MTs’ privacy and proved that the UDP algorithm can satisfy the requirement of LDP under a certain privacy level by properly selecting the STD of additive noise processes. Then, we have shown that there is an optimal number of communication rounds (T𝑇T) in terms of convergence performance for a given protection level, which has motivated us to design an intelligent scheme for adaptively choosing the value of T𝑇T. To address this problem, we have proposed a CRD method for training an FL model, which will be triggered when the convergence performance stops improving. Our experiments have demonstrated that this discounting method in the UDP algorithm can obtain a better tradeoff between convergence performance and privacy levels. We have also noted that various initial values of T𝑇T and discounting factors β𝛽\beta bring out different convergence results.

It is noteworthy that the privacy budget allocation scheme greatly affects the quality of the FL training and the proposed CRD method also can be improved if we can obtain an exact FL performance prediction. As a topic for future, it is of interest to design an effective privacy budget allocation scheme to improve the convergence performance with a given privacy level.

(58)

Hence, the convergence bound can be given as

𝔼​{F​(𝒘T)}−F​(𝒘∗)≤AT​(F​(𝒘0)−F​(𝒘∗))+(1−AT)​(κ0​T​KU2​∑i=1Uln⁡(1/δi)ϵi2+κ1​U​(U−K)K​(U−1)),𝔼𝐹superscript𝒘𝑇𝐹superscript𝒘superscript𝐴𝑇𝐹superscript𝒘0𝐹superscript𝒘1superscript𝐴𝑇subscript𝜅0𝑇𝐾superscript𝑈2superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑈1subscript𝛿𝑖superscriptsubscriptitalic-ϵ𝑖2subscript𝜅1𝑈𝑈𝐾𝐾𝑈1\mathbb{E}\{F(\boldsymbol{w}^{T})\}-F(\boldsymbol{w}^{*})\leq A^{T}(F(\boldsymbol{w}^{0})-F(\boldsymbol{w}^{*}))\\ +(1-A^{T})\left(\frac{\kappa_{0}TK}{U^{2}}\sum_{i=1}^{U}\frac{\ln(1/\delta_{i})}{\epsilon_{i}^{2}}+\frac{\kappa_{1}U(U-K)}{K(U-1)}\right), (59)

where A=1−2​μ​η+μ​η2​L𝐴12𝜇𝜂𝜇superscript𝜂2𝐿A=1-2\mu\eta+\mu\eta^{2}L, κ0=L2​Δ​ℓ2μsubscript𝜅0superscript𝐿2Δsuperscriptℓ2𝜇\kappa_{0}=\frac{L^{2}\Delta\ell^{2}}{\mu} and κ1=η2​L2​ε2​μsubscript𝜅1superscript𝜂2superscript𝐿2𝜀2𝜇\kappa_{1}=\frac{\eta^{2}L^{2}\varepsilon}{2\mu}. This completes the proof. □□\hfill\square
